title: Top Colleges in the Northeast by Size
sub_head: The region has more than half of the nation’s top 10 small schools and midsize schools in the WSJ/THE College Rankings
body:
The Northeast is home to the country’s highest-ranked large school, in terms of undergraduate enrollment, in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings, as well as the highest-ranked midsize school and two schools tied for No. 2 nationwide among small colleges.
The WSJ/THE rankings are based on 15 factors across four main categories: Forty percent of each school’s overall score comes from student outcomes, including measures of graduate salaries and debt burdens, 30% from the school’s academic resources, including how much it spends on teaching, 20% from how well it engages its students and 10% from its environment, a measure of the diversity of its students and faculty.
Schools with fewer than 3,000 undergraduates are considered small in these rankings, those with 3,000 to 10,000 undergrads are midsize and those with more than 10,000 are large.
Two liberal-arts schools in Massachusetts, Amherst College and Williams College, are ranked highest among small schools in the Northeast. Their No. 21 ranking among all schools nationwide makes them No. 2 among small schools in the country. Four other Northeastern schools are among the top 10 small colleges nationwide: Wellesley College, Swarthmore College, Middlebury College and Haverford College. Their rankings among all schools in the country range from No. 29 to No. 40.
Harvard University is the top-ranked midsize school in the Northeast and is the highest-ranked college of any size in the country. Four other midsize Northeastern schools are among the top 10 overall nationwide: the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Yale University, Brown University and Princeton University. Dartmouth College, No. 12 overall, is also among the top 10 midsize schools in the country.
